remarks: New Living Translation: Dear brothers and sisters, when troubles come your way, consider it an opportunity for great joy.
Not an instruction for the non-believer
applications: Jesus: Tells use to pray that we don't fall into them
James: Consider it joy when they do come.
Can I see trials as the testing of my faith?
Of course not all trials are from God.
Can I put aside myself to see what God is trying to teach me.?
Emphasis that this is not me powering through it, but his spirit allowing me to see and endure.

remarks: Enduring the trial makes us perfect and complete.
This process of enduring trials, leading to steadfastness and ultimately please God is a recurring theme.
applications: What is a trial to you? He states trials of many kinds.
Start small: What really annoys me?
Co-worker or boss does this or that: great joy
That person who I really have a hard time loving.
Some things I really do not do well with
Start to turn around my way of thinking.
Cure for the victim mentality.
Someone who God Loves and has taken and interest in. Who's Spirit is working in.

remarks: Lord of Glory: 1). our glorious Lord Jesus Christ, 2). Shekinah Glory
The word favoritism in Greek literally means to receive someone according to their face.
Describing the essence of judging someone by their appearance.
James is not saying simply ignore our differences.
For instance: It is a natural thing to be curious about someone who looks different.
For example: traveling to another country and having people look at you.
One thing to be curious about differences, another to show partiality based on simularities or differences.
Warns us about combining favoritism with faith in Jesus Christ.
applications: Poor and rich as a hypothetical example of judging a book by it's cover
Gives us insight to how our heart betrays us.

remarks: The word for poor (πτωχός) is the Greek term for the most severe forms of poverty, implying “destitute,” someone without virtually any resources.
Same word for shabby (filthy) as 1:21 where he refers to moral filthiness.
Treated the rich man preferentially.
Discriminated against the poor man.
Only difference between this two is there appearance and maybe their scent.
Judges with evil thoughts

Default state.
Verse 2.
Teachers: Who is James talking about?
Many people find themselves teaching.
Whether by profession...
School teachers laboring with students, or a college professor.
or by circumstance...
Youtube person telling me how fix my car or computer.
James isn't really addressing these teachers, he is addressing those who teach others about God.
Whether that a preacher by profession or someone finds themselves in a circumstance teaching someone, James doesn't distinguish.
It could be anyone proclaiming information to others about God. (e.g. bible study leader, parent teaching a child, evangelist...)
applications: ------ We all stumble and make mistakes. -----
Can you remember a time you have made a mistake on the job, I mean a really big mistake, firing level mistake?
Maybe you haven't yet. Maybe you have taken steps to prevent this.
Maybe you've learned from your co-worker's mistakes, so you're more careful, work harder, learn so this doesn't happen to you.
------ Medical Malpractice -----
In my profession, medicine, you know it's just a matter of time before that mistake comes to your door.(100% chance of malpractice after 20 years of practice)
It's usually failure to diagnosis. Missing something.
Hospitals and insurers are vigilant about risk managment and risk mitigation
Fair amount of money involved, contributes to the cost of health care.
Little girl with meningitis
Some infections are so sneaky.
No matter how hard you try, how much you study, learn from others..., it happens.
Little like the game of dodge ball. Keep dodging, seeing those around you being hit, as long as you are in the game, the balls keep coming at you.
------Spiritual Malpractice -----
James is telling us with regard to teachers, it is just a matter of time before the teacher commits spiritual malpractice with their teaching.
We all stumble in many ways.
The teacher may work hard, pray hard, but they are not perfect and will eventually stumble in what they say.
Just like some diseases are so sneeky, so are the wisdom and religions of men.
As long as they are opening their mouth and teaching, they are at risk of spiritual malpractice.
------ Judgement -----
When I stumble at work I damage the flesh, but when I stumble as a teacher the damage I cause is far more grave and permanent, damaging the soul.
The physician knows that stumbling can lead to a medical malpractice judgement.
James is telling the teacher to know stumbling in what we teach will lead to a stricter judgement, something far more serious than a medical malpractice.
But these risks really don't compare to the risks taken standing here talking in front of you.
Discussion of the Jesus words to the pharisee.(Matt 23,Luke 11)
Not many of you should become teachers, my brothers...
But before he scares us all away from teaching, he gives us a couple of examples of how something so little can be used for good.

remarks: See verse 4.
Two examples of how small things are good and helpful.
Small bit allows the rider to direct the whole body of the horse.
Just like someone who can control their tongue, they bridle their whole body.
Gives another, more extreme, example of a small thing controlling enormous forces: Look also...
applications: Modern example: gas pedal; power switch, keyboard; cell phone.
Tongue is also small thing, but can accomplish much good. (Proverbs versesm part a).
Just like the gas pedal or the cell phone can be used for good and evil so can the tongue.
